trial_identification.studytitle: A Study of Changes in Quality of Life as a Measure of Interventions in Patients with Cancer
trial_identification.scientifictitle: A randomized study of intercessory prayer to improve the spiritual well being and quality of life of patients being treated for cancer

conditions.healthcondition: Spiritual Wellbeing in patients being treated for cancer

interventions.interventions: Intercessory Prayer of unspecified duration to be determined by prayers usually daily over a 6 months period. They complete qualiry of life and spirtiual wellbeing scales at entry then 6 months later.
interventions.comparator: Observation by completing quality of life and spiritual wellbeing scales without an intervention

primaryOutcome.outcome: Change in spiritual wellbeing score on Functional Assessment of Chronic Illness Therapy - Spirituality (FACIT-Sp) scale
primaryOutcome.timepoint: 6 months after entering the trial and completing the initial quality of life and spiritual wellbeing measures

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Quality of Life as measured by the Functional Assessment of Chronic Illness Therapy- General and the Mental Adjustment to Cancer scales

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: cancer diagnosis, age over 18 years, the ability to read English, ability to consent, having a prognosis of greater than 6 months
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Unable to complete questionnaires in English Prognosis less than 6 months

trial_design.concealment: Consecutive new patients with cancer presenting to the Cancer Centre and treatment alllocated by random sequence. Allocation involved contacting the the holder of the allocation schedule who was at a central administration site and not responsible for determining the eligibility of a subject
trial_design.sequence: Pre existing random sequence generated and given to independent data management team

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Randomised trial to assess the impact of intercessory prayer on spritual wellbeing od patients presenting wioth cancer to the Royal Adelaide Hospital Cancer Centre
